meta.dc:subject: legislation
meta.dc:rights: The Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

main.longTitle: An Ordinance to provide for restrictions in connection with operating vessels, and performing certain duties on board vessels, in the waters of Hong Kong after consumption or use of alcohol or drugs; to provide for procedures to obtain specimens of breath, blood and urine, and to test for the presence of alcohol and drugs in the specimens and for impairment by drugs; to provide for disqualification from operating vessels and performing certain duties on board vessels on conviction of certain offences; to provide for enforcement powers; and to provide for related matters.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title

subsection.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Marine Safety (Alcohol and Drugs) Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance—
subsection.def: approved breath analyzing instrument (認可呼氣分析儀器) means an instrument of a type approved under section 46(1)(a);
approved screening instrument (認可檢查儀器) means an instrument of a type approved under section 46(1)(b);

authorized officer (獲授權人員) means—(a)the Director;(b)a public officer of the Marine Department of or above the rank of Marine Inspector Class II;(c)a police officer of or above the rank of Sergeant; or(d)a public officer authorized under section 44;
designated test centre (指定測試中心) means a place, vehicle or vessel designated to be a test centre under section 47(1);
Director (處長) means the Director of Marine;

drug (藥物) means—(a)a specified illicit drug; or(b)any other substance (other than alcohol) that, when consumed or used by a person, deprives the person of any of the person’s normal mental or physical faculties temporarily or permanently;

dynamically supported craft (動力承托的航行器) means a craft that is operable on or above water and the weight of which (or a significant part of which) is balanced in one mode of operation by forces other than hydrostatic forces;
enrolled nurse (登記護士) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Nurses Registration Ordinance (Cap. 164);
hospital (醫院) means an institution that provides medical or surgical treatment for in-patients or out-patients;

junk (中式帆船) includes any vessel—(a)of Chinese or other Asiatic build, construction and rig;(b)of Chinese or other Asiatic build and construction, but of European rig; or(c)of European build and construction, but of Chinese or other Asiatic rig,whether such vessel is of a sea-going type or not, and whether such vessel is mechanically propelled or not;
local vessel (本地船隻) has the meaning given by section 2 of the Merchant Shipping (Local Vessels) Ordinance (Cap. 548);
Marine Field Sobriety Test (海上現場清醒度測試) means any, or a combination of any or all, of the tests specified under section 46(2);

marine traffic offence (海上交通罪行) means an offence under any of the following Ordinances or under any subsidiary legislation made under any of them—(a)the Pilotage Ordinance (Cap. 84);(b)the Shipping and Port Control Ordinance (Cap. 313);(c)the Merchant Shipping (Safety) Ordinance (Cap. 369);(d)the Merchant Shipping (Seafarers) Ordinance (Cap. 478);(e)the Merchant Shipping (Local Vessels) Ordinance (Cap. 548);
master (船長), in relation to a vessel, means the person (except a pilot) having for the time being command or charge of the vessel;

operate (操作), in relation to a vessel, means—(a)to determine, to exercise control over, or to be in charge of, the course or direction of the vessel or the means of propulsion of the vessel;(b)to exercise a function in connection with the navigation of the vessel; or(c)to pilot the vessel under the Pilotage Ordinance (Cap. 84);
owner (擁有人), in relation to a vessel, means—(a)the person registered as the owner of the vessel; or(b)in the absence of such registration, the person owning the vessel;
Part 2 offence (第2部罪行) means an offence under section 5, 6, 9 or 12;
Part 3 offence (第3部罪行) means an offence under section 16, 17, 18, 24 or 27;
pilot (領港員、領港) has the meaning given by section 2 of the Pilotage Ordinance (Cap. 84);
preliminary drug test (初步藥物測試) means—(a)a Marine Field Sobriety Test;(b)a Rapid Oral Fluid Test; or(c)a urine screening test;

prescribed limit (訂明限度) means—(a)22 micrograms of alcohol in 100 millilitres of breath;(b)50 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of blood; or(c)67 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of urine;
Rapid Oral Fluid Test (快速口腔液測試) means a test carried out on a person’s oral fluid by means of an instrument of a type approved under section 46(1)(c);
registered dentist (註冊牙醫) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Dentists Registration Ordinance (Cap. 156);
registered nurse (註冊護士) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Nurses Registration Ordinance (Cap. 164);
screening breath test (檢查呼氣測試) means a test carried out on a specimen of a person’s breath by means of an approved screening instrument;
Secretary (局長) means the Secretary for Transport and Logistics;
specified illicit drug (指明毒品) means a substance specified in the Schedule;
urine screening test (尿液檢查測試) means a test carried out on a person’s urine by means of an instrument of a type approved under section 46(1)(d);

vessel (船隻) includes—(a)any ship, junk, boat, dynamically supported craft, seaplane, and any other description of vessel that is used in navigation; and(b)any other description of vessel that is not used, or not constructed or adapted for use, in navigation.

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a reference to the performance of a designated duty on board a vessel is a reference to the performance of a duty relating to the following on board a vessel—

subparagraph.content: the safety of the vessel;
the security of the vessel; or
the protection of the marine environment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a reference to a vessel that is underway is a reference to a vessel that is not at anchor, made fast to the shore or aground.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Meaning of ordering that a person be disqualified

subsection.content: In this Ordinance, a reference to ordering that a person be disqualified on conviction of an offence has the meaning given by subsection (2), (3) or (4).

If the offence is for contravening section 5(1), 6(1), 16(1), 17(1) or 18(1), the reference is a reference to ordering that the person not be allowed to operate a vessel that is underway in the waters of Hong Kong.

If the offence is for contravening section 5(2), 6(2), 16(2), 17(2) or 18(2), the reference is a reference to ordering that the person not be allowed to perform any designated duty on board a vessel that is underway in the waters of Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: If the offence is one under section 9(1), 12(1)(a) or (b), 24(1)(a), (b) or (c) or 27(1)(a) or (b)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a person who, before committing the offence, operated a vessel that was underway—the reference is a reference to ordering that the person not be allowed to operate a vessel that is underway in the waters of Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a person who, before committing the offence, performed a designated duty on board a vessel that was underway—the reference is a reference to ordering that the person not be allowed to perform any designated duty on board a vessel that is underway in the waters of Hong Kong.

subsection.content: In this Ordinance, a reference to ordering that a person not be disqualified is to be construed accordingly.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Application
section.leadIn: This Ordinance applies to a vessel (other than a warship) in the waters of Hong Kong, including a vessel for the time being used by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an Office set up by the Central People’s Government in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, other than the Hong Kong Garrison of the Chinese People’s Liberation Army; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the government of a foreign state.

part.name: P2
part.heading: Operating Vessels or Performing Designated Duties: Restrictions regarding Alcohol

section.name: s5
section.heading: Operating vessel or performing designated duty under influence of alcohol

subsection.content: A person must not operate a vessel that is underway while the person is under the influence of alcohol to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the vessel.

A person must not perform any designated duty on board a vessel that is underway while the person is under the influence of alcohol to such an extent as to be incapable of performing the designated duty properly on board the vessel.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable—

subparagraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 2 offence, whether on summary conviction or on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or
in any other case—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence in accordance with subsection (3), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 2 offence—for a period of not less than 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case—for a period of not less than 5 years.

subsection.content: However, the court or magistrate may for special reasons order that the person be disqualified for a shorter period, or that the person not be disqualified.

For the purposes of subsection (3)(a) or (4), if, as at the date on which the offence was committed by a person, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction of a Part 2 offence, the person is regarded as having never previously been convicted of any Part 2 offence.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Operating vessel or performing designated duty while alcohol concentration exceeds limit

subsection.content: A person must not operate a vessel that is underway while the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine exceeds the prescribed limit.
A person must not perform any designated duty on board a vessel that is underway while the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine exceeds the prescribed limit.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable—

subparagraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 2 offence, whether on summary conviction or on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or
in any other case—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.content: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence in accordance with subsection (3), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified for a period specified in subsection (6).
However, the court or magistrate may for special reasons order that the person be disqualified for a shorter period, or that the person not be disqualified.

subsection.leadIn: The period is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 2 offence—

subparagraph.content: if the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 1—a period of not less than 6 months;
if the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 2—a period of not less than 12 months; or
if the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 3—a period of not less than 2 years; or
if the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 1—a period of not less than 2 years;
if the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 2—a period of not less than 3 years; or
if the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 3—a period of not less than 5 years.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (6)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the proportion of alcohol in a person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 1 if it exceeds the prescribed limit but is less than—

subparagraph.content: for breath—35 micrograms of alcohol in 100 millilitres of breath;
for blood—80 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of blood; or
for urine—107 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of urine;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the proportion of alcohol in a person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 2 if it exceeds tier 1 but is less than—

subparagraph.content: for breath—66 micrograms of alcohol in 100 millilitres of breath;
for blood—150 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of blood; or
for urine—201 milligrams of alcohol in 100 millilitres of urine; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the proportion of alcohol in a person’s breath, blood or urine is tier 3 if it exceeds tier 2.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (3)(a) or (6), if, as at the date on which the offence was committed by a person, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction of a Part 2 offence, the person is regarded as having never previously been convicted of any Part 2 offence.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Alternative offences for person charged under section 5 or 6
section.leadIn: On the trial of a person charged with an offence in relation to a vessel under section 5(3) or 6(3), the person may be acquitted of the offence and be found guilty of one or more offences under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a local vessel—section 32 of the Merchant Shipping (Local Vessels) Ordinance (Cap. 548); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for any other vessel—section 72 of the Shipping and Port Control Ordinance (Cap. 313).

division.name: D2
division.heading: Requirements on Specimens and Related Offences

section.name: s8
section.heading: Providing specimen for screening breath test

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may require any of the following persons to provide a specimen of breath for a screening breath test—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who is operating, or attempting to operate, a vessel that is underway;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who is performing, or attempting to perform, any designated duty on board a vessel that is underway;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: a person whom the officer has reasonable cause to—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: having been operating, or attempting to operate, a vessel that was underway while alcohol was in the person’s body; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: still having alcohol in the person’s body;

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: having been operating, or attempting to operate, a vessel that was underway; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: having committed a marine traffic offence while the vessel was underway;

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: having been performing, or attempting to perform, any designated duty on board a vessel that was underway while alcohol was in the person’s body; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: still having alcohol in the person’s body; or

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: having been performing, or attempting to perform, any designated duty on board a vessel that was underway; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: having committed a marine traffic offence while the vessel was underway.

subsection.leadIn: Also, an authorized officer may require a person to provide a specimen of breath for a screening breath test if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an accident occurred owing to the presence of a vessel that was underway; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the officer has reasonable cause to suspect that, at the time of the accident, the person was—

subparagraph.content: operating, or attempting to operate, the vessel; or
performing, or attempting to perform, any designated duty on board the vessel.

subsection.leadIn: For a requirement under subsection (1) or (2), the authorized officer may require the person to provide the specimen—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at or near the place where the requirement is made; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at a designated test centre, a police station, or a hospital, specified by the officer.

subsection.content: An authorized officer must, at the time of requiring a person to provide a specimen under subsection (1) or (2), warn the person that a failure to provide it may render the person liable to prosecution.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may arrest a person without a warrant if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as a result of a screening breath test, the officer has reasonable cause to suspect that the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath exceeds the prescribed limit; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person fails to provide a specimen of breath for a screening breath test when required to do so under this section.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Failure to provide specimen for screening breath test

subsection.leadIn: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to provide a specimen of breath for a screening breath test when required to do so under section 8 commits an offence and is liable—

subparagraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 2 offence, whether on summary conviction or on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or
in any other case—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), a person fails to provide a specimen of breath for a screening breath test, if the specimen—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is not sufficient to enable the test to be carried out; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is not provided in a way to enable the objective of the test to be satisfactorily achieved.

subsection.leadIn: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence in accordance with subsection (1), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 2 offence—for a period of not less than 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case—for a period of not less than 5 years.

subsection.content: However, the court or magistrate may for special reasons order that the person be disqualified for a shorter period, or that the person not be disqualified.

For the purposes of subsection (1)(a) or (3), if, as at the date on which the offence was committed by a person, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction of a Part 2 offence, the person is regarded as having never previously been convicted of any Part 2 offence.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Providing specimen for alcohol analysis or laboratory test

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), an authorized officer may require any of the persons specified in subsection (2) to provide—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a specimen of breath for alcohol analysis by means of an approved breath analyzing instrument; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a specimen of blood or urine for a laboratory test.

subsection.leadIn: The following persons are specified for the purposes of subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person whose screening breath test indicates that the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath is likely to exceed the prescribed limit;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who, with reasonable excuse, fails to provide a specimen of breath for a screening breath test.

subsection.leadIn: The authorized officer may require the person to provide a specimen of blood or urine under subsection (1) only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the officer has reasonable cause to believe that, for medical reasons, a specimen of breath cannot be provided or should not be required; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: at the time the requirement is made—

subparagraph.content: an approved breath analyzing instrument is not available on the vessel concerned, or at the designated test centre, the police station or the hospital, where the requirement is made; or
it is not practicable to use an approved breath analyzing instrument for any other reason.

subsection.leadIn: For a requirement under this section to provide a specimen other than a specimen of breath—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), the authorized officer who makes the requirement must decide whether the specimen is to be of blood or urine; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a medical practitioner is of the opinion that, for medical reasons, a specimen of blood cannot or should not be taken, the specimen required to be provided must be a specimen of urine.

subsection.content: A requirement under this section to provide a specimen of breath, blood or urine may only be made on the vessel concerned, or at a designated test centre, a police station or a hospital.

For a requirement under this section to provide a specimen of urine, the authorized officer who makes the requirement must decide whether the specimen is to be provided on the vessel concerned, or at a designated test centre, a police station or a hospital.

subsection.leadIn: If a person is required to provide a specimen of urine under this section, the person must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provide a first sample of urine for discard; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide a second sample of urine within 1 hour of the requirement as the specimen.

subsection.content: An authorized officer must, at the time of requiring a person to provide a specimen under this section, warn the person that a failure to provide it may render the person liable to prosecution.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Supplementary provision on specimen of blood for laboratory test

subsection.content: If a person is required to provide a specimen of blood for a laboratory test under section 10, the specimen must be taken from the person by a medical practitioner, a registered nurse, or an enrolled nurse, specified by the authorized officer who makes the requirement.
A specimen of blood may only be taken from a person with the person’s consent.

subsection.leadIn: However, the authorized officer may request a medical practitioner to take a specimen of blood from a person without the person’s consent if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the officer is entitled to require the person to provide a specimen of breath under section 8(1)(c) or (2), and it appears to the officer that, for medical reasons, the person may be incapable of providing a specimen of breath and of giving valid consent to the taking of a specimen of blood; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the officer is entitled to require the person to provide a specimen of blood under section 10(1)(b) or (3), and it appears to the officer that, for medical reasons, the person may be incapable of giving valid consent to the taking of a specimen of blood.

subsection.leadIn: If the medical practitioner to whom a request is made under subsection (3) considers it appropriate, it is lawful for the medical practitioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to take a specimen of blood from the person without the person’s consent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to provide the specimen to the authorized officer who made the request, without the person’s consent.

subsection.content: A specimen of blood may be taken under subsection (4) only on the vessel concerned, or at a designated test centre, a police station or a hospital.

subsection.leadIn: A specimen of blood taken under subsection (4) may be subjected to a laboratory test only if the person from whom it was taken—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has been informed that it was taken;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has been required by the authorized officer to give consent to its analysis for the purpose of evidence in the relevant investigation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has given the consent.

subsection.content: An authorized officer must, at the time of requiring a person to give consent under subsection (6)(b), warn the person that a failure to give consent may render the person liable to prosecution.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Failure to provide specimen for, or give consent to, alcohol analysis or laboratory test

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to provide a specimen of breath, blood or urine for alcohol analysis or a laboratory test when required to do so under section 10; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to give consent when required to do so under section 11(6)(b).

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

subparagraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 2 offence, whether on summary conviction or on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or
in any other case—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), a person fails to provide a specimen of breath, blood or urine for alcohol analysis or a laboratory test, if the specimen—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is not sufficient to enable the alcohol analysis or laboratory test to be carried out; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is not provided in a way to enable the objective of the alcohol analysis or laboratory test to be satisfactorily achieved.

subsection.leadIn: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence in accordance with subsection (2), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 2 offence—for a period of not less than 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case—for a period of not less than 5 years.

subsection.content: However, the court or magistrate may for special reasons order that the person be disqualified for a shorter period, or that the person not be disqualified.

For the purposes of subsection (2)(a) or (4), if, as at the date on which the offence was committed by a person, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction of a Part 2 offence, the person is regarded as having never previously been convicted of any Part 2 offence.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Protection for hospital patients

subsection.leadIn: A person at a hospital as a patient must not be required to provide—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a specimen of breath for a screening breath test or alcohol analysis; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a specimen of blood or urine for a laboratory test,

subsection.continued: unless the medical practitioner in immediate charge of the person’s case has been notified of the proposal to require such a specimen to be provided at the hospital.

subsection.leadIn: The requirement must not be made if the medical practitioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: objects on the ground specified in subsection (3); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: states in writing the diagnosis justifying the objection.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (2), the ground is that providing a specimen mentioned in subsection (1) would be prejudicial to the proper care and treatment of the patient.
To avoid doubt, this section does not apply to the taking of a specimen of blood under section 11(4).

section.name: s14
section.heading: Evidence in relation to specimen

subsection.content: Evidence that a specimen of urine was taken from a person under section 10 by an authorized officer or a medical practitioner may be given by producing a document that certifies that fact and purports to be signed by the officer or medical practitioner (as the case may be).

Evidence that a specimen of blood was taken from a person under section 11(1) with the person’s consent by a medical practitioner, a registered nurse or an enrolled nurse may be given by producing a document that certifies that fact and purports to be signed by the medical practitioner, registered nurse or enrolled nurse (as the case may be).

Evidence that a specimen of blood was taken from a person under section 11(4) by a medical practitioner may be given by producing a document that certifies that fact and purports to be signed by the medical practitioner.

Evidence that a specimen of blood was subjected to a laboratory test in compliance with section 11(6) may be given by producing a document that certifies that fact and purports to be signed by the authorized officer who made the requirement to give consent under section 11(6)(b).

section.name: s15
section.heading: Evidence in relation to alcohol in specimen

subsection.content: This section applies in relation to a specimen taken under Division 2.

subsection.leadIn: Evidence of the proportion of alcohol in a specimen of breath may be given by producing one or more documents that purport to be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a statement automatically produced by the approved screening instrument, or approved breath analyzing instrument, that measured the proportion of alcohol in the specimen; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a certificate (whether or not contained in the same document as the statement) signed by an authorized officer certifying that—

subparagraph.content: the statement relates to the specimen provided by the person concerned at the date and time shown in the statement; and
the approved screening instrument, or approved breath analyzing instrument, was operated correctly and properly when the specimen was being taken.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person provides a specimen of breath under section 8 and another specimen of breath under section 10; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: evidence of the proportion of alcohol in each specimen is given under subsection (2),

subsection.continued: the court or magistrate must use the statement relating to the specimen with the lower proportion of alcohol out of the specimens and disregard the other.

subsection.content: Evidence of the proportion of alcohol in a specimen of blood or urine may be given by producing a document that purports to be a certificate under section 25 of the Evidence Ordinance (Cap. 8) as to the proportion of alcohol found in the specimen of blood or urine identified in the certificate.

Evidence of the proportion of alcohol in a specimen of breath, blood or urine provided by a person is evidence that the proportion of alcohol in the person’s breath, blood or urine at the time of the alleged offence was not less than that in the specimen.

subsection.leadIn: If, at the time a specimen of blood or urine was provided by a person, the person asked to be provided with a part of the specimen, evidence of the proportion of alcohol found in the specimen is not admissible unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the part of the specimen in which the alcohol was found is one of 2 parts into which the specimen provided by the person was divided at the time it was provided; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the other part was provided to the person.

subsection.leadIn: If a specimen of blood was taken from a person under section 11(4) and, at the time the person consented to its analysis, the person asked to be provided with a part of the specimen, evidence of the proportion of alcohol found in the specimen is not admissible unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the part of the specimen in which the alcohol was found is one of 2 parts into which the specimen taken from the person was divided at the time it was taken; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the other part was provided to the person.

part.name: P3
part.heading: Operating Vessels or Performing Designated Duties: Restrictions regarding Drugs

section.name: s16
section.heading: Operating vessel or performing designated duty under influence of specified illicit drug

subsection.content: A person must not operate a vessel that is underway while the person is under the influence of a specified illicit drug to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the vessel.

A person must not perform any designated duty on board a vessel that is underway while the person is under the influence of a specified illicit drug to such an extent as to be incapable of performing the designated duty properly on board the vessel.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), a person is under the influence of a specified illicit drug to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of a vessel if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person’s ability to operate the vessel properly is for the time being impaired; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the concentration of a specified illicit drug (or of a combination of specified illicit drugs) found in the person’s blood or urine would usually result in a person being unable to operate a vessel properly.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), a person is under the influence of a specified illicit drug to such an extent as to be incapable of performing any designated duty properly if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person’s ability to perform the designated duty properly is for the time being impaired; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the concentration of a specified illicit drug (or of a combination of specified illicit drugs) found in the person’s blood or urine would usually result in a person being unable to perform any designated duty properly.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable—

subparagraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence, whether on summary conviction or on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or
in any other case—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence in accordance with subsection (5), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence—for a period of not less than 5 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case—for a period of not less than 10 years.

subsection.content: However, the court or magistrate may for special reasons order that the person be disqualified for a shorter period, or that the person not be disqualified.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (6), the court or magistrate may order that the person be disqualified for life on conviction of the offence concerned (subject offence) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person has previously been convicted of an offence for contravening subsection (1) or (2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: having regard to the circumstances in which the subject offence was committed and the behaviour of the person, the court or magistrate is of the opinion that it is undesirable for the person to continue to be allowed—

subparagraph.content: where the subject offence is an offence for contravening subsection (1)—to operate a vessel that is underway; or
where the subject offence is an offence for contravening subsection (2)—to perform any designated duty on board a vessel that is underway.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (5)(a), (6) or (8)(a), if, as at the date on which the offence was committed by a person, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction of a Part 3 offence, the person is regarded as having never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Operating vessel or performing designated duty with any concentration of specified illicit drug

subsection.content: A person must not operate a vessel that is underway while any concentration of a specified illicit drug (with or without any other drug) is present in the person’s blood or urine.

A person must not perform any designated duty on board a vessel that is underway while any concentration of a specified illicit drug (with or without any other drug) is present in the person’s blood or urine.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable—

subparagraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence, whether on summary conviction or on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or
in any other case—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence in accordance with subsection (3), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence—for a period of not less than 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case—for a period of not less than 5 years.

subsection.content: However, the court or magistrate may for special reasons order that the person be disqualified for a shorter period, or that the person not be disqualified.

For the purposes of subsection (3)(a) or (4), if, as at the date on which the offence was committed by a person, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction of a Part 3 offence, the person is regarded as having never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Operating vessel or performing designated duty under influence of other drug

subsection.content: A person must not operate a vessel that is underway while the person is under the influence of a drug other than a specified illicit drug (non-specified drug) to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the vessel.

A person must not perform any designated duty on board a vessel that is underway while the person is under the influence of a non-specified drug to such an extent as to be incapable of performing the designated duty properly on board the vessel.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), a person is under the influence of a non-specified drug to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of a vessel if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person’s ability to operate the vessel properly is for the time being impaired; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the concentration of a non-specified drug (or of a combination of non-specified drugs) found in the person’s blood or urine would usually result in a person being unable to operate a vessel properly.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), a person is under the influence of a non-specified drug to such an extent as to be incapable of performing any designated duty properly if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person’s ability to perform the designated duty properly is for the time being impaired; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the concentration of a non-specified drug (or of a combination of non-specified drugs) found in the person’s blood or urine would usually result in a person being unable to perform any designated duty properly.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable—

subparagraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence, whether on summary conviction or on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or
in any other case—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence in accordance with subsection (5), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence—for a period of not less than 6 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case—for a period of not less than 2 years.

subsection.content: However, the court or magistrate may for special reasons order that the person be disqualified for a shorter period, or that the person not be disqualified.

For the purposes of subsection (5)(a) or (6), if, as at the date on which the offence was committed by a person, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction of a Part 3 offence, the person is regarded as having never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence.

division.name: D2
division.heading: Supplementary Provisions on Offences under Division 1

section.name: s19
section.heading: Defence for offence under section 16 or 17

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under section 16(5) to prove that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the specified illicit drug (or the combination of specified illicit drugs) found in the person’s blood or urine was lawfully obtained;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person did not know, and could not reasonably have known, that, if consumed or used in accordance with advice, the drug (or the combination of drugs) found in the blood or urine would render the person incapable of—

subparagraph.content: for an offence for contravening section 16(1)—having proper control of the vessel; or
for an offence for contravening section 16(2)—performing the designated duty properly; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person consumed or used the drug (or the combination of drugs) in accordance with the advice.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under section 17(3) to prove—

subparagraph.content: if only 1 specified illicit drug was present in the person’s blood or urine—that drug; or
if more than one specified illicit drug was present in the person’s blood or urine—each of the drugs,

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the person consumed or used that drug or the drugs in accordance with advice.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsections (1) and (2), a specified illicit drug is lawfully obtained if a healthcare professional prescribes it for, or administers or supplies it to, the person charged.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: advice (指示), in relation to a specified illicit drug, means written or oral advice given by the healthcare professional who prescribed, administered or supplied the drug;

healthcare professional (醫護專業人員) means—(a)a medical practitioner;(b)a registered dentist;(c)a person whose name is entered on the register of pharmacists under section 5 of the Pharmacy and Poisons Ordinance (Cap. 138); or(d)a person acting under the direction or supervision of a person mentioned in paragraph (a), (b) or (c).

section.name: s20
section.heading: Defence for offence under section 18

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under section 18(5) to prove that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the non-specified drug (or the combination of non-specified drugs) found in the person’s blood or urine was lawfully obtained;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person did not know, and could not reasonably have known, that, if consumed or used in accordance with advice, the drug (or the combination of drugs) found in the blood or urine would render the person incapable of—

subparagraph.content: for an offence for contravening section 18(1)—having proper control of the vessel; or
for an offence for contravening section 18(2)—performing the designated duty properly; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person consumed or used the drug (or the combination of drugs) in accordance with the advice.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), a non-specified drug is lawfully obtained if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a healthcare professional prescribes it for, or administers or supplies it to, the person charged;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: it is a pharmaceutical product as defined by section 2(1) of the Pharmacy and Poisons Ordinance (Cap. 138)—

subparagraph.content: that is registered as mentioned in regulation 36 of the Pharmacy and Poisons Regulations (Cap. 138 sub. leg. A); and
for the sale of which a prescription is not required by Hong Kong law; or
a proprietary Chinese medicine as defined by section 2(1) of the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549); and
registered under section 121 of that Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: advice (指示)—(a)in relation to a non-specified drug described in subsection (2)(a), means—(i)written or oral advice given by the healthcare professional who prescribed, administered or supplied the drug; or(ii)information on a label, as defined by section 2(1) of the Pharmacy and Poisons Ordinance (Cap. 138), that accompanies the prescribed or supplied drug;(b)in relation to a non-specified drug described in subsection (2)(b), means information on a label, as defined by section 2(1) of the Pharmacy and Poisons Ordinance (Cap. 138), that accompanies the drug; or(c)in relation to a non-specified drug described in subsection (2)(c), means information on the package insert, as defined by section 2(1) of the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549), that is supplied with the drug;

healthcare professional (醫護專業人員) means—(a)a medical practitioner;(b)a registered dentist;(c)a registered Chinese medicine practitioner, or a listed Chinese medicine practitioner, as defined by section 2(1) of the Chinese Medicine Ordinance (Cap. 549);(d)a person whose name is entered on the register of pharmacists under section 5 of the Pharmacy and Poisons Ordinance (Cap. 138); or(e)a person acting under the direction or supervision of a person mentioned in paragraph (a), (b), (c) or (d);
non-specified drug (非指明藥物) means a drug other than a specified illicit drug.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Offence under section 17 or 18 instead of section 16

subsection.leadIn: If, on the trial of a person charged with an offence under section 16(5) for contravening section 16(1), the prosecution—

subparagraph.content: the person operated, or attempted to operate, a vessel that was underway; and
a specified illicit drug was present in the person’s blood or urine; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: does not prove that the person was under the influence of the drug to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the vessel,

subsection.continued: the person must be acquitted of the offence, but may be found guilty of an offence under section 17.

subsection.leadIn: If, on the trial of a person charged with an offence under section 16(5) for contravening section 16(2), the prosecution—

subparagraph.content: the person performed, or attempted to perform, any designated duty on board a vessel that was underway; and
a specified illicit drug was present in the person’s blood or urine; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: does not prove that the person was under the influence of the drug to such an extent as to be incapable of performing the designated duty properly,

subsection.continued: the person must be acquitted of the offence, but may be found guilty of an offence under section 17.

subsection.leadIn: If, on the trial of a person charged with an offence under section 16(5) for contravening section 16(1), the prosecution proves that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person operated, or attempted to operate, a vessel that was underway; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person was under the influence of a drug, but not a specified illicit drug, to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of the vessel,

subsection.continued: the person must be acquitted of the offence, but may be found guilty of an offence under section 18.

subsection.leadIn: If, on the trial of a person charged with an offence under section 16(5) for contravening section 16(2), the prosecution proves that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person performed, or attempted to perform, any designated duty on board a vessel that was underway; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person was under the influence of a drug, but not a specified illicit drug, to such an extent as to be incapable of performing the designated duty properly,

subsection.continued: the person must be acquitted of the offence, but may be found guilty of an offence under section 18.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Alternative offences for person charged under section 16, 17 or 18

subsection.leadIn: On the trial of a person charged with an offence in relation to a vessel under section 16(5), 17(3) or 18(5), the person may be acquitted of the offence and be found guilty of one or more offences under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a local vessel—section 32 of the Merchant Shipping (Local Vessels) Ordinance (Cap. 548); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for any other vessel—section 72 of the Shipping and Port Control Ordinance (Cap. 313).

subsection.content: To avoid doubt, section 19(1) or (2) or 20(1) does not apply to an offence under a provision mentioned in subsection (1)(a) or (b).

division.name: D3
division.heading: Requirements on Tests and Specimens and Related Offences

section.name: s23
section.heading: Preliminary drug test

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may require any of the following persons to undergo one or more preliminary drug tests—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who is operating, or attempting to operate, a vessel that is underway;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who is performing, or attempting to perform, any designated duty on board a vessel that is underway;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: a person whom the officer has reasonable cause to—

subparagraph.leadIn: suspect of having been operating, or attempting to operate, a vessel that was underway—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: while any concentration of a specified illicit drug was present in the person’s blood or urine; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: while under the influence of any drug;

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: having been operating, or attempting to operate, a vessel that was underway; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: having committed a marine traffic offence while the vessel was underway;

subparagraph.leadIn: suspect of having been performing, or attempting to perform, any designated duty on board a vessel that was underway—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: while any concentration of a specified illicit drug was present in the person’s blood or urine; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: while under the influence of any drug; or

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: having been performing, or attempting to perform, any designated duty on board a vessel that was underway; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: having committed a marine traffic offence while the vessel was underway.

subsection.leadIn: Also, an authorized officer may require a person to undergo one or more preliminary drug tests if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an accident occurred owing to the presence of a vessel that was underway; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the officer has reasonable cause to suspect that, at the time of the accident, the person was—

subparagraph.content: operating, or attempting to operate, the vessel; or
performing, or attempting to perform, any designated duty on board the vessel.

subsection.leadIn: For a requirement under subsection (1) or (2), a preliminary drug test may be carried out—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at or near the place where the requirement is made; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at a designated test centre, a police station, or a hospital, specified by the officer.

subsection.content: For a Rapid Oral Fluid Test, the authorized officer may require the person under subsection (1) or (2) to provide one or more specimens of oral fluid.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer must, at the time of requiring a person to undergo a preliminary drug test under subsection (1) or (2), warn the person that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person may be required to undergo more than one preliminary drug test; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a failure to undergo any of the tests the person is required to undergo, or to provide any specimen the person is required to provide, may render the person liable to prosecution.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may arrest a person without a warrant if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as a result of a Marine Field Sobriety Test carried out on the person, the officer has reasonable cause to suspect that the person has committed an offence under section 16(5), 17(3) or 18(5);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: as a result of a Rapid Oral Fluid Test carried out on the person, the officer has reasonable cause to suspect that any concentration of a specified illicit drug is present in the person’s oral fluid; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: as a result of a urine screening test carried out on the person, the officer has reasonable cause to suspect that any concentration of a specified illicit drug is present in the person’s urine.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may arrest a person without a warrant if the person fails to do any of the following when required to do so under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: undergo a Marine Field Sobriety Test;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide a specimen of oral fluid for a Rapid Oral Fluid Test;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: provide a specimen of urine for a urine screening test.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Failure to undergo, or provide specimen for, preliminary drug test

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to undergo a Marine Field Sobriety Test when required to do so under section 23;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to provide a specimen of oral fluid for a Rapid Oral Fluid Test when required to do so under section 23; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: fails to provide a specimen of urine for a urine screening test when required to do so under section 23.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

subparagraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence, whether on summary conviction or on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or
in any other case—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), a person fails to provide a specimen of oral fluid for a Rapid Oral Fluid Test, or a specimen of urine for a urine screening test, if the specimen—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is not sufficient to enable the test to be carried out; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is not provided in a way to enable the objective of the test to be satisfactorily achieved.

subsection.leadIn: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence in accordance with subsection (2), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence—for a period of not less than 5 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case—for a period of not less than 10 years.

subsection.content: However, the court or magistrate may for special reasons order that the person be disqualified for a shorter period, or that the person not be disqualified.

For the purposes of subsection (2)(a) or (4), if, as at the date on which the offence was committed by a person, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction of a Part 3 offence, the person is regarded as having never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Providing specimen for laboratory test

subsection.content: An authorized officer may require any of the persons specified in subsection (2) to provide a specimen of blood or urine, or specimens of both blood and urine, for a laboratory test.

subsection.leadIn: The following persons are specified for the purposes of subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person whose Marine Field Sobriety Test indicates that the person’s ability to operate a vessel properly, or to perform a designated duty properly, is for the time being impaired;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person whose Rapid Oral Fluid Test or urine screening test indicates that any concentration of a specified illicit drug is present in the person’s oral fluid or urine;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: a person who, with reasonable excuse, fails to—

subparagraph.content: undergo a Marine Field Sobriety Test;
provide a specimen of oral fluid for a Rapid Oral Fluid Test; or
provide a specimen of urine for a urine screening test.

subsection.leadIn: Also, an authorized officer may require a person on whom a preliminary drug test could not be carried out due to a medical reason to provide a specimen of blood or urine, or specimens of both blood and urine, for a laboratory test, if the officer has reasonable cause to suspect that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any concentration of a specified illicit drug is present in the person’s blood, urine or oral fluid; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person is under the influence of any drug.

subsection.leadIn: For a requirement under this section to provide a specimen—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), the authorized officer who makes the requirement must decide whether the specimen is to be of blood or urine, or specimens of both blood and urine; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a medical practitioner is of the opinion that, for medical reasons, a specimen of blood cannot or should not be taken, the specimen required to be provided must be a specimen of urine.

subsection.content: A requirement under this section to provide a specimen of blood or urine may only be made on the vessel concerned, or at a designated test centre, a police station or a hospital.

For a requirement under this section to provide a specimen of urine, the authorized officer who makes the requirement must decide whether the specimen is to be provided on the vessel concerned, or at a designated test centre, a police station or a hospital.
If a person is required to provide a specimen of urine under this section, the person must provide it within 1 hour of the requirement.
An authorized officer must, at the time of requiring a person to provide a specimen under this section, warn the person that a failure to provide it may render the person liable to prosecution.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Supplementary provision on specimen of blood for laboratory test

subsection.content: If a person is required to provide a specimen of blood for a laboratory test under section 25, the specimen must be taken from the person by a medical practitioner, a registered nurse, or an enrolled nurse, specified by the authorized officer who makes the requirement.
A specimen of blood may only be taken from a person with the person’s consent.

subsection.leadIn: However, the authorized officer may request a medical practitioner to take a specimen of blood from a person without the person’s consent if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the officer is entitled to require the person to undergo a preliminary drug test under section 23(1) or (2), and it appears to the officer that, for medical reasons, the person may be incapable of undergoing the test and of giving valid consent to the taking of a specimen of blood; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the officer is entitled to require the person to provide a specimen of blood under section 25(1) or (3), and it appears to the officer that, for medical reasons, the person may be incapable of giving valid consent to the taking of a specimen of blood.

subsection.leadIn: If the medical practitioner to whom a request is made under subsection (3) considers it appropriate, it is lawful for the medical practitioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to take a specimen of blood from the person without the person’s consent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to provide the specimen to the authorized officer who made the request, without the person’s consent.

subsection.content: A specimen of blood may be taken under subsection (4) only on the vessel concerned, or at a designated test centre, a police station or a hospital.

subsection.leadIn: A specimen of blood taken under subsection (4) may be subjected to a laboratory test only if the person from whom it was taken—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has been informed that it was taken;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has been required by the authorized officer to give consent to its analysis for the purpose of evidence in the relevant investigation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has given the consent.

subsection.content: An authorized officer must, at the time of requiring a person to give consent under subsection (6)(b), warn the person that a failure to give consent may render the person liable to prosecution.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Failure to provide specimen for, or give consent to, laboratory test

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to provide a specimen of blood or urine for a laboratory test when required to do so under section 25; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to give consent when required to do so under section 26(6)(b).

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

subparagraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence, whether on summary conviction or on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or
in any other case—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 12 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), a person fails to provide a specimen of blood or urine for a laboratory test, if the specimen—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is not sufficient to enable the laboratory test to be carried out; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is not provided in a way to enable the objective of the laboratory test to be satisfactorily achieved.

subsection.leadIn: If a court or magistrate convicts a person of an offence in accordance with subsection (2), the court or magistrate must order that the person be disqualified—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person has never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence—for a period of not less than 5 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case—for a period of not less than 10 years.

subsection.content: However, the court or magistrate may for special reasons order that the person be disqualified for a shorter period, or that the person not be disqualified.

For the purposes of subsection (2)(a) or (4), if, as at the date on which the offence was committed by a person, at least 5 years have elapsed since the person’s last conviction of a Part 3 offence, the person is regarded as having never previously been convicted of any Part 3 offence.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Protection for hospital patients

subsection.leadIn: A person at a hospital as a patient must not be required to provide—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a specimen of oral fluid for a Rapid Oral Fluid Test;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a specimen of urine for a urine screening test; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a specimen of blood or urine for a laboratory test,

subsection.continued: unless the medical practitioner in immediate charge of the person’s case has been notified of the proposal to require such a specimen to be provided at the hospital.

subsection.leadIn: The requirement must not be made if the medical practitioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: objects on the ground specified in subsection (3); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: states in writing the diagnosis justifying the objection.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (2), the ground is that providing a specimen mentioned in subsection (1) would be prejudicial to the proper care and treatment of the patient.
To avoid doubt, this section does not apply to the taking of a specimen of blood under section 26(4).

section.name: s29
section.heading: Specimen may also be used to test for alcohol
section.content: A specimen of blood or urine taken under section 25 or 26 may, in addition to being used in a laboratory test for any drug, be used in a laboratory test for alcohol in connection with an alleged offence under Division 1 of Part 2.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Evidence in relation to specimen

subsection.content: Evidence that a specimen of urine was taken from a person under section 25 by an authorized officer or a medical practitioner may be given by producing a document that certifies that fact and purports to be signed by the officer or medical practitioner (as the case may be).

Evidence that a specimen of blood was taken from a person under section 26(1) with the person’s consent by a medical practitioner, a registered nurse or an enrolled nurse may be given by producing a document that certifies that fact and purports to be signed by the medical practitioner, registered nurse or enrolled nurse (as the case may be).

Evidence that a specimen of blood was taken from a person under section 26(4) by a medical practitioner may be given by producing a document that certifies that fact and purports to be signed by the medical practitioner.

Evidence that a specimen of blood was subjected to a laboratory test in compliance with section 26(6) may be given by producing a document that certifies that fact and purports to be signed by the authorized officer who made the requirement to give consent under section 26(6)(b).

section.name: s31
section.heading: Evidence in relation to drug in specimen

subsection.content: This section applies in relation to a specimen taken under Division 3.

subsection.leadIn: Evidence of whether a person’s ability to operate a vessel properly, or to perform a designated duty properly, was impaired by the consumption or use of a drug may be given by producing a document that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: purports to be the opinion of the authorized officer who carried out the Marine Field Sobriety Test as to whether the person’s ability to operate a vessel properly, or to perform a designated duty properly, was impaired; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: purports to be signed by the officer who carried out the Marine Field Sobriety Test.

subsection.content: Evidence of the presence of a drug in a specimen of blood or urine may be given by producing a document that purports to be a certificate under section 25 of the Evidence Ordinance (Cap. 8) as to the presence of the drug found in the specimen of blood or urine identified in the certificate.

Evidence of the concentration of a drug in a specimen of blood or urine may be given by producing a document that purports to be a certificate under section 25 of the Evidence Ordinance (Cap. 8) as to the concentration of the drug found in the specimen of blood or urine identified in the certificate.
Evidence of the presence of a drug in a specimen of blood or urine provided by a person is evidence of the presence of the drug in the person’s blood or urine at the time of the alleged offence.

Evidence of the concentration of a drug in a specimen of blood or urine provided by a person is evidence that the concentration of the drug in the person’s blood or urine at the time of the alleged offence was not less than that in the specimen.

subsection.leadIn: If, at the time a specimen of blood or urine was provided by a person, the person asked to be provided with a part of the specimen, evidence of the presence of, or the concentration of, a drug found in the specimen is not admissible unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the part of the specimen in which the drug was found is one of 2 parts into which the specimen provided by the person was divided at the time it was provided; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the other part was provided to the person.

subsection.leadIn: If a specimen of blood was taken from a person under section 26(4) and, at the time the person consented to its analysis, the person asked to be provided with a part of the specimen, evidence of the presence of, or the concentration of, a drug found in the specimen is not admissible unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the part of the specimen in which the drug was found is one of 2 parts into which the specimen taken from the person was divided at the time it was taken; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the other part was provided to the person.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Power to stop and board vessel

subsection.content: An authorized officer may at any time stop and board a vessel for requiring a person who has been operating, or has been performing any designated duty on board, the vessel that was underway to undergo a screening breath test or a preliminary drug test.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may at any time stop and board a vessel for making any examination or investigation that may be necessary if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any offence under this Ordinance has been committed in respect of the vessel or by any person on board the vessel; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the officer has reasonable cause to suspect that any offence under this Ordinance has been committed, is being committed or is about to be committed in respect of the vessel or by any person on board the vessel.

subsection.content: An authorized officer boarding a vessel under subsection (1) or (2) may take with the officer any persons necessary to assist the officer for the purposes of this section.
The master of a vessel, when required to stop the vessel by an authorized officer under subsection (1) or (2), must stop the vessel and permit the officer to board the vessel.
A person who, without reasonable excuse, contravenes subsection (4) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 2.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Power to investigate

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of an investigation made by an authorized officer under section 32(2), the officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may require the vessel that the officer has boarded or any part of it, or anything in it, to be left undisturbed (whether generally or in particular respects) for so long as is necessary to carry out the investigation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may take any measurements and photographs, and make any recordings, that the officer considers necessary;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may observe, inspect and search the vessel or the person referred to in section 32(2)(a) or (b) (suspect), and seize and remove from the vessel or from a person any article or substance in respect of which the officer has reasonable cause to suspect that an offence under this Ordinance has been committed;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: may, for an article or substance removed under paragraph (c), detain it for so long as is necessary—

subparagraph.content: to examine it and to cause it to be subjected to any process or test;
to ensure that it is not tampered with before the examination of it is completed; or
to ensure that it is available for use as evidence in any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: may require any person whom the officer has reasonable cause to believe to be able to give any information relevant to the investigation (informant) to answer (in the absence of persons, other than a person nominated by the informant to be present or any persons whom the officer may allow to be present) any questions that the officer considers appropriate to ask, and to sign a declaration of the truth of the informant’s answers;

subparagraph.content: require the suspect to give to the officer the suspect’s name, address and telephone number and any other personal particulars that the officer may reasonably require; and

require the production by the suspect of, inspect, and take copies of any entry in, the log book of the vessel, or any document (including an identity card issued under the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177) or other documentary evidence of identity) that is necessary for the officer to see for the purpose of the investigation; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: may detain the suspect for a reasonable period while the officer inquires about the suspected commission of the offence.

subsection.leadIn: If an authorized officer requires a person to answer any question under subsection (1)(e), neither the question asked, nor the answer given, is admissible in evidence against the person in criminal proceedings other than proceedings for any of the following offences in respect of the answer or the declaration of the truth of the answer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an offence for contravening subsection (1)(e);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an offence under subsection (3)(b);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an offence under Part V of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200).

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person contravenes a requirement made by an authorized officer under subsection (1);

subparagraph.content: the answer given, or the declaration signed, by the person under subsection (1)(e) is false or misleading in a material particular; and
the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the answer or the declaration is false or misleading in a material particular; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the person prevents any other person from appearing before an authorized officer or from answering any question to which an authorized officer may require an answer under subsection (1)(e).

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (3) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Authorized officer may require certain information

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an accident occurred owing to the presence of a vessel that was underway; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person is suspected of having committed an offence under this Ordinance while operating a vessel or performing any designated duty on board a vessel,

subsection.continued: an authorized officer may require the owner of the vessel or the owner’s agent to comply with the requirements under subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The requirements are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to inform the authorized officer orally the name and address of the master of the vessel, or the person operating the vessel or performing any designated duty on board the vessel, at the time of the occurrence or alleged offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to furnish to the authorized officer, within a reasonable time after the occurrence or alleged offence, a written statement signed by the owner or the owner’s agent (as the case may be), specifying the name and address of the master of the vessel, or the person operating the vessel or performing any designated duty on board the vessel, at the time of the occurrence or alleged offence.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), the owner of a vessel or the owner’s agent commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 2 and to imprisonment for 6 months—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the owner or the owner’s agent (as the case may be) fails to comply with the requirements under subsection (2); or

subparagraph.content: the statement furnished by the owner or the owner’s agent (as the case may be) under subsection (2)(b) is false or misleading in a material particular; and
the owner or the owner’s agent (as the case may be) knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the statement is false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.content: In proceedings for an offence under subsection (3), it is a defence to show that the owner of a vessel or the owner’s agent (as the case may be) did not know, and could not with reasonable diligence have ascertained, the name or address of the master of the vessel, or the person operating the vessel or performing any designated duty on board the vessel, at the time of the occurrence or alleged offence.

subsection.leadIn: A person is to be taken to have established a matter that needs to be established for the defence under subsection (4) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sufficient evidence is adduced to raise an issue with respect to that matter; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Power to arrest and give directions

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may arrest and remove from a vessel any person whom the officer has reasonable cause to suspect of having committed an offence under this Ordinance, and take the person to a police station to be dealt with in accordance with the Police Force Ordinance (Cap. 232); and

paragraph.name: b
