paragraph.content: may direct a vessel (in respect of which the officer has reasonable cause to suspect that an offence under this Ordinance has been committed) to proceed together with any persons on board to the nearest Marine Police Base or office of the Marine Department, or any place that the officer directs.

subsection.leadIn: If an authorized officer has reasonable cause to suspect that an offence under this Ordinance has been committed by a person (suspect) in respect of a vessel, the officer—

subparagraph.content: the suspect to stop operating, or attempting to operate, the vessel; and
the owner, agent or master of the vessel to arrange within a specified period a competent person to operate the vessel;
the suspect to stop performing, or attempting to perform, any designated duty on board the vessel; and
the owner, agent or master of the vessel to arrange within a specified period a competent person to perform the designated duty on board the vessel; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may direct the owner, agent or master of the vessel to arrange to bring the suspect ashore immediately.

subsection.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a direction given under subsection (1)(b) or (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: agent (代理人), in relation to a vessel, means a person acting in Hong Kong as an agent for the owner of the vessel;

competent person (合資格人員)—(a)in relation to operating a vessel, means a person who may lawfully operate the vessel; or(b)in relation to performing a designated duty on board a vessel, means a person who may lawfully perform the designated duty on board the vessel.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Power to enter premises

subsection.leadIn: If an authorized officer knows, or has reason to suspect, that a vessel that relates to an offence under this Ordinance is in or on any non-domestic premises, the officer may, on producing (if so required) a duly authenticated document showing the officer’s authority—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enter such premises at any reasonable time; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: inspect and search any person (suspect) whom the authorized officer has reasonable cause to suspect of having committed any offence under this Ordinance, and exercise the powers under section 8 or 23.

subsection.leadIn: A magistrate may issue a warrant authorizing an authorized officer to enter any non-domestic premises, by force if necessary, if satisfied by information on oath—

subparagraph.leadIn: admission to the premises has been refused, or refusal is reasonably expected, and either—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: notice of the intention to apply for a warrant has been given to the occupier of the premises; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the giving of the notice would defeat the object of the entry;
the premises are unoccupied, or the occupier is temporarily absent; or
the case is urgent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds to enter the premises for any of the purposes specified in subsection (4).

subsection.leadIn: A magistrate may issue a warrant authorizing an authorized officer to enter any domestic premises at any time, by force if necessary, if satisfied by information on oath—

subparagraph.content: the premises are unoccupied, or the occupier is temporarily absent;
the case is urgent; or

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: notice of the intention to apply for a warrant has been given to the occupier of the premises; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the giving of the notice would defeat the object of the entry; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds to enter the premises for any of the purposes specified in subsection (4).

subsection.leadIn: The purposes are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to ascertain whether any person has committed an offence under this Ordinance;

subparagraph.content: the vessel or any part of it;
the suspect; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to take any action authorized or required to be taken by or under this Ordinance in respect of the vessel or suspect.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer entering any premises with a warrant issued under subsection (2) or (3), may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: inspect or search the premises or any part of the premises;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: observe, inspect or search the suspect;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: require the suspect to produce to the officer for inspection the suspect’s identity card issued under the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177) or the suspect’s other documentary evidence of identity;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: take with the officer any persons the officer considers necessary; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: take any action authorized or required to be taken by or under this Ordinance in respect of the vessel or suspect.

subsection.content: On leaving any unoccupied premises, the authorized officer must leave the premises as effectually secured against trespassers as the officer found the premises to be at the time of entry.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: domestic premises (住宅處所) means any premises used wholly or mainly for residential purposes and constituting a separate household unit;
non-domestic premises (非住宅處所) means any premises other than domestic premises.

section.name: s37
section.heading: Notice to appear before magistrate in respect of offences

subsection.content: Despite section 8 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227), if an authorized officer reasonably suspects that an offence under this Ordinance has been committed by a person on board a vessel (suspect), the officer may serve a notice on the suspect in accordance with subsection (2) requiring the suspect to appear before a magistrate to be dealt with according to law.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (1) may be served by an authorized officer on a suspect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: personally;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by handing the notice personally to the senior officer on board the vessel; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by handing the notice personally to the person appearing to be in charge or command of the vessel at the time of such service.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (1) must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in the prescribed form;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be signed by an authorized officer by whom it is served; and

subparagraph.content: the name of the suspect on whom it is served and the name of the vessel which the suspect is on board;
the offence that is alleged to have been committed with sufficient particulars of the offence;
the time and place at which the offence is alleged to have been committed; and
the time and place at which the suspect is required to appear.

subsection.leadIn: If a suspect on whom a notice under subsection (1) has been served fails to appear before a magistrate at the time and place stated in the notice, and it is made to appear to the magistrate by oath that the notice was served on the suspect in accordance with subsection (2), the magistrate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may issue a warrant for the apprehension of the suspect and to bring the suspect before the magistrate or another magistrate to be dealt with according to law; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (if a warrant is issued under paragraph (a)) must endorse on the warrant the amount of bail, if any, on which the suspect may be released in the meantime.

subsection.leadIn: If a suspect on whom a notice under subsection (1) has been served appears before a magistrate in accordance with the notice, or is brought before a magistrate by a warrant issued under subsection (4)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the magistrate may hear and determine the offence alleged in the notice as if a complaint had been made or an information had been laid against the suspect in respect of the offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (for the purposes of paragraph (a)) the provisions of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227) relating to the hearing of a complaint or information and the related proceedings are to apply with necessary modifications.

subsection.content: If a suspect on whom a notice under subsection (1) has been served is brought before a magistrate by a warrant issued under subsection (4), the magistrate may, in addition to any other penalty, order the suspect to pay costs, of not more than $400, solely in respect of the warrant.
Any costs ordered to be paid under subsection (6) are recoverable under section 14 of the Costs in Criminal Cases Ordinance (Cap. 492) as a civil debt due to the Government.
The Director may, by notice published in the Gazette, prescribe the form as mentioned in subsection (3)(a).

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: senior officer (高級船員), in relation to a vessel, means the master, chief officer, or chief engineer or second engineer, employed or engaged on board the vessel on the business of the vessel.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Use of log book etc. in evidence

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance, any specified entry, or a document purporting to be a copy of any such entry and to be certified as a true copy by any of the persons specified in subsection (2), is, until the contrary is proved—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to be admitted in evidence and be sufficient evidence of the matters stated in it; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: (in the case of such a copy) to be presumed that it is so certified.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), the persons who may certify copies of specified entries are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director or any person authorized by the Director in writing in that behalf;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a magistrate;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a notary public, as defined by section 2(1) of the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a consular officer.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: specified entry (指明記項) means—(a)an entry in the log book, if any, of a vessel or any similar document; or(b)an entry in a document that is necessary for an authorized officer to see for the purpose of an investigation under section 33(1)(f).

section.name: s39
section.heading: Proof of identity of master etc. in proceedings
section.leadIn: If, in any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance involving a vessel, there is produced to a court or magistrate a statement furnished under section 34(2) that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: purports to have been signed by the owner of the vessel or the owner’s agent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: states that the owner or the owner’s agent (as the case may be) was the master of the vessel, or the person operating the vessel or performing any designated duty on board the vessel, at the time of the offence,

section.continued: the court or magistrate must admit, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, the statement as evidence that the owner or the owner’s agent (as the case may be) was the master of the vessel, or the person operating the vessel or performing any designated duty on board the vessel, at the time of the offence.

section.name: s40
section.heading: Proof of identity of agent in proceedings
section.content: If, in any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance involving any person appointed as an agent for the owner of a vessel, there is produced to a court or magistrate a notice of appointment signed by the owner and the person so appointed, the court or magistrate must admit, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, the notice as evidence that the person was the agent for the owner at the time of the offence.

section.name: s41
section.heading: Obstruction

subsection.content: Any person who obstructs an authorized officer performing or exercising any function, duty or power under this Ordinance commits an offence.
The owner of a vessel, the owner’s agent or the master of a vessel who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 2 years.
Any other person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s42
section.heading: Giving of directions and offence of non-compliance

subsection.content: A direction given under this Ordinance may be given orally or in writing, or by means of signals.
If requested by any person who is given a direction orally or by means of signals, the person giving the direction must confirm the direction in writing.

subsection.leadIn: Even if a direction given under this Ordinance has not been confirmed in writing under subsection (2), the direction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be complied with immediately; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a time limit for compliance is specified in the direction, must be complied with within the time limit.

subsection.content: If a direction may be given to the master of a vessel under this Ordinance, it is sufficient for the direction to be given to a person on board the vessel who is on duty to accept any direction on behalf of the master.

For the purposes of subsection (4), if there is no master for the vessel or the master of the vessel cannot be traced, the direction may be given to the owner of the vessel or the owner’s agent, or to any other person who appears to the person giving the direction to be in control of the vessel at that time.

subsection.leadIn: The giving of a direction to the master of a vessel under this Ordinance does not diminish or in any way affect the responsibility of the master in relation to any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the vessel;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the persons on board the vessel;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the cargo on the vessel;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other person or property.

subsection.content: Without limiting any other express penalty for failure to comply with a direction, any person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a direction given to him or her under this Ordinance commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s43
section.heading: Reasonable excuse

subsection.content: This section applies if a provision of this Ordinance that creates an offence makes a reference to a reasonable excuse for an act or omission.
The reference to a reasonable excuse is to be construed as providing for a defence to a charge in relation to the act or omission.

subsection.leadIn: A person is to be taken to have established that the person had a reasonable excuse for the act or omission if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sufficient evidence is adduced to raise an issue that the person had such a reasonable excuse; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Authorizing officers
section.content: The Director may authorize in writing a public officer as an authorized officer for the purposes of this Ordinance.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Protection for authorized officers

subsection.content: An authorized officer is not personally liable for any civil liability or claim whatever in respect of any act done or omitted to be done by the officer, if the officer did or omitted to do the act in the honest belief that the act or omission was required, or authorized, by or under this Ordinance.
The protection conferred by subsection (1) does not in any way affect the liability of the Government for the act or omission of the authorized officer.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Approving instrument types and specifying tests

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, by notice published in the Gazette, approve—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a type of instrument for analyzing the proportion of alcohol in a specimen of breath;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a type of instrument for indicating whether the proportion of alcohol in a person’s breath is likely to exceed the prescribed limit;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a type of instrument for detecting the presence of any specified illicit drug in a person’s oral fluid; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a type of instrument for detecting the presence of any specified illicit drug in a person’s urine.

subsection.content: The Director may, by notice published in the Gazette, specify the tests that are to be carried out by an authorized officer on a person, so as to assist the officer to form an opinion as to whether the person’s ability to operate a vessel properly, or to perform a designated duty properly, is impaired by the consumption or use of drugs.

section.name: s47
section.heading: Designating test centres

subsection.content: The Commissioner of Police or the Director may, by notice published in the Gazette, designate a place, vehicle or vessel to be a test centre.
A notice under subsection (1) is not subsidiary legislation.

section.name: s48
section.heading: Amending prescribed limit

subsection.content: The Secretary may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend the definition of prescribed limit in section 2(1) by varying the proportion of alcohol that constitutes the prescribed limit.

A notice under subsection (1) is not to come into operation until after the period mentioned in section 34(2) of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) (as may be extended under section 34(3) or (4) of that Ordinance) has expired.

section.name: s49
section.heading: Amending tier 1, tier 2 or tier 3

subsection.content: The Secretary may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend section 6(7) by varying the proportion of alcohol that constitutes tier 1, tier 2 or tier 3 under paragraph (a), (b) or (c) of that section.

A notice under subsection (1) is not to come into operation until after the period mentioned in section 34(2) of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) (as may be extended under section 34(3) or (4) of that Ordinance) has expired.

section.name: s50
section.heading: Amending Schedule

subsection.content: The Secretary may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend the Schedule.

A notice under subsection (1) is not to come into operation until after the period mentioned in section 34(2) of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) (as may be extended under section 34(3) or (4) of that Ordinance) has expired.

Ketamine
Methamphetamine (methylamphetamine)
Cannabis or any active ingredient of cannabis
